data.title: Pursuing Christ (and Punk Rock Music)
data.meta_description: Any photos from the mid-to-late 1990s would verify this, I’m sure. Like many other boy classmates, I spent my school years thinking of three things: sports, girls, and God. Not always in that order…
data.text:
Taped inside the door to my mustard-colored high school locker were three things:

A photo of NBA dunking legend Shawn Kemp

A magazine cutout of celeb crush Danielle Fishel (Topanga from Boy Meets World)

A Bible verse, likely Philippians 4:13

Any photos from the mid-to-late 1990s would verify this, I’m sure. Like many other boy classmates, I spent my school years thinking of three things: sports, girls, and God. Not always in that order, though God was usually third.

At home, my walls weren’t vastly different than my locker. Sports stars were plastered around along with pennants and pictures ripped from Sports Illustrated magazines. Any pictures of women on my walls were the safe type, mostly Christian singers such as Rebecca St. James and Jaci Velasquez. Other Christian musicians made their place alongside Chipper Jones and Deion Sanders, such as Audio Adrenaline, DC Talk, and Jars of Clay, just to name a few.

For a boy who struggled with any real talent for playing instruments, music became a constant means of survival. Regardless of where I was, who I was with, or what I was doing, there was music playing either via the car radio…
